document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the Thyropygus allevatus group. Part 3: the T. induratus subgroup (Diplopoda: Spirostreptida: Harpagophoridae)

Diagnosis. A species of the
induratus
subgroup. Differing from all other species in the subgroup by having one or more denticles in the middle of tibial spine ( ti ) and by having anterior coxal fold ( ac ) apically bent abruptly mesad with an acute narrowed, slender tip.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Thyropygus resimus
(specimen from Phu-Kum-Khao), gonopods. A: anterior view, left telopodite removed. B: posterior view, left telopodite removed. C, D: left telopodite, posterior-mesal view. E: left telopodite, anterior-lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gonopods (
Figs. 3
A–E): Anterior coxal fold ( ac ) (
Fig. 3
A) basally slender, becoming broader towards tip, apically bent abruptly mesad, with acute, slender tip. Posterior coxal fold ( pc ) (
Fig. 3
B) basally with moderately high lateral paracoxites ( px ); mesal process ( pmp ) slightly lower than ac , forming shelf ( sh ) for accommodation of telopodite, distally directed distolaterad. Telopodite (
Figs. 3
C–E) leaving coxite over shelf of posterior coxal fold; femoral spine ( fe ) relatively long, curving in a horizontal plane, in situ resting along apical part of ac ; tibial spine ( ti ) very long, slender, curving in an oblique-sagittal plane, in the middle sometimes with a single denticle ( de ) (rarely with several denticles) directed laterally, its tip in situ close to tip of fe and ac ; apical part: lamellar lobe ( ll ) broad, rounded, transparent; palette ( pa ) simple, basally with an uncate subterminal lobe ( usl ) ventrally; distally with about six to eight brownish blepharochaetae ( bp ).

Notes. Colour: some specimens are overall dark brown, some are reddish brown; specimens from Laos have a longitudinal brown band mid-dorsally on the body, not seen in Thai specimens. The gonopods show some variation of the tip of anterior coxal fold ( ac ): some specimens with a relatively short, blunt tip, others with a narrower, relatively long, almost sharp tip. The femoral spine ( fe ) is relatively short in some specimens, but in Tak and Kamphaengphet specimens it is much longer and is distinctly crenulated along its inner curvature. The tibial spine ( ti ) has a denticle ( de ) (sometimes several denticles) on the outer margin at mid-length or slightly further distal in some specimens, others lack such denticles.

Concerning
Thyropisthus resimus sensu
Demange ( 1961 )
, see above under
T. induratus
. The specimen from “Northern Thailand Silang” recorded as
T. confusus tenuispinus
by
Demange ( 1983 )
is in fact a
T. resimus
, see list of material for interpretation of ‘Silang’. A specimen from the orchid museum, Bangkok, also recorded as
T. confusus tenuispinus
by
Demange ( 1983 )
is in fact a
T. allevatus
. These are so far the only records of
T. confusus
from Thailand , so this species should be removed from the list of Thai species.
